"WASHINGTON — The House acted with rare bipartisanship on Tuesday to approve legislation that would reopen the federal Export-Import Bank, after a debate that underscored the split between the party’s traditional pro-business members and ascendant free-market conservatives who are suspicious of big corporations. The lopsided final vote of 313 to 118 belied that split, as a majority of Republicans allied with all but one Democrat to reauthorize the 81-year-old bank agency, but only once the bill’s passage was assured. Late Monday, just a quarter of Republicans supported an earlier vote — and an unusual legislative move — that made the final vote possible over the opposition of most party leaders."

http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/258547-dems-blocked-on-ex-im-reauthorization An attempt by Democrats to reauthorize the Export-Import Bank was blocked on the Senate floor Thursday. Sen. Maria Cantwell (D-Wash.) tried to get unanimous consent to pass a stand-alone bill that would reauthorize the bank's charter through September 2019 after lawmakers allowed it to expire in June.  But she was blocked by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who opposes the Ex-Im Bank. The Republican leader was one of 29 members who voted against reauthorizing the bank as part of a long-term highway bill earlier this year. 

"I would remind my colleagues that we've voted on the reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank already. There are numerous objections on this side of the aisle," he said, adding that because of those objections he would block Cantwell's request. 

Pressure has been growing for the Senate to move a stand-alone bill after the House voted to reauthorize the bank's charter by a 313-118 vote . . . 

"I would hope over here the Republican leader would move forward on this now," Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) said Wednesday. "We should get this done this week." 

Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D-N.D.) added on Thursday that supporters need to reauthorize the Export-Import Bank "now." 

"We can't wait another minute. We can't wait another day," she said. "I'm still a little shocked when people say we can't get that done because we need to introduce a vehicle." 

The House-passed bill was fast-tracked earlier Thursday on behalf of Democratic supporters. The process allows the bill to be placed directly on the Senate calendar, where it could be scheduled for a vote. 

McConnell, however, has given no indication that he's willing to move a stand-alone bill. He stressed his opposition earlier this week, saying that Export-Import Bank legislation would not get floor time in the Senate. 

"The way to achieve Ex-Im, if it's going to be achieved in the Senate, would be in the context of the highway bill," he told reporters Tuesday.

McConnell has repeatedly signaled the best way to move Ex-Im legislation would be to tie it to a larger bill funding highways.  
~~~~~~~

Lack of enthusiasm by Senate Majority Leader McConnell, combined with the few remaining days that the Senate will be in session, makes passage before the forecast horizon highly unlikely. The last day the Senate is scheduled to be in session this year is Dec. 20. Even if it were to meet this deadline, would Obama sign before Jan. 1? The earliest possible day would be Oct. 19, the first day after the current recess. Assuming it would be voted upon and pass (highly likely) it goes to the Senate. It will go into recess Nov. 9-13 and 23-27.  That leaves only nine working days between recesses, and fifteen working days -- perhaps eighteen if they work Saturdays -- in December. In the usual course of Senate events, the bill must be voted out of committee, and, the big sticking point, McConnell must schedule a vote by the entire Senate. Meanwhile, the House and Senate have some other important issues: should they shut down the government? Should they schedule default on ithe nation's sovereign debt, stop mailing out Social Security checks, defund Planned Parenthood, etc.? http://blogs.rollcall.com/218/hoyer-hints-boehner-wants-vote-reauthorize-ex-im/ Unlike Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Whip Steve Scalise, Boehner has never permanently shut the door to the concept of reauthorization, though he has said the House would only consider it under two specific scenarios. One is if Rep. Jeb Hensarling, R-Texas, advances a reauthorization bill out of the Financial Services Committee, of which he is the chairman. But Hensarling is one of Congress’ most vocal Ex-Im Bank opponents and has shown no signs of moving anything anytime soon. The other is if the Senate sends reauthorization language over to the House, in which case the chamber would vote on it through an open amendment process, which hasn’t happened, either. Perhaps Boehner’s biggest hint about his stance came in late April, when he told reporters thousands of jobs would “disappear quickly” if the Ex-Im Bank were to expire. Bank supporters seized on the remarks as vindication, and just this week General Electric announced it would be moving 500 jobs outside the United States due to Congress’ disinclination to restore full funding to the agency. But if Boehner has anything else to say on the subject — something that would be particularly encouraging to Hoyer and other House Democrats — Boehner’s spokeswoman Emily Schillinger wouldn’t let on.

Since this question is only open through the end of the year, I'll start with a low forecast. Export Import Bank, created in 1934, cannot issue new loans since it's funding ended on 6/30/15.  However, it has not reduced it's staff of 420 employees, as it is legally mandated to manage it's existing potfolio of loans, loan guarantees and insurance provided to foreign customers of US exporters.
  The bank has political support from Democrats and pro-business Republicans (seen as promoting US jobs, promoting US business against foreign competition and by US firms as a way to reallocate foreign loan risk from US business to the US taxpayer). Support also comes from pro business organizations like the Chamber of Commerce, which is an important source of campaign funds for many Republicans. Opposition to the Bank is from the anti-government Republicans who argue against corporate wealfare.  Most sources indicate that the Bank does provide US benefits, supporting business sales and US jobs while also providing net profits to the treasury from fees, interest, etc.
   Senate leadership has passed a highway funding bill that includes provisions for the EX IM Bank, however the House leadership is against consideration of this version of the high way bill.
  Given this scenario, it seems likely that the negotiation and passage of a re-authorization bill may take some time.  Reports indicate that the Chamber of Commerce will take action in the next primary against Republican candidates who do not support 1) the Ex IM bank, 2) Immagration reform, 3) a long term highway funding bill.  Still this Bank, is still performing it's ongoing responsibilities with no loss of personnel, the Chamber threat will take time to force changes, even though the House will likely pass re-authorization at some point, there doesn't seem to be an immediate need for the House leadership to drop the philosophical disagreement so soon.
